THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 18, 1916.

URGES INTEREST IN COMPETITION
Dean Brush Points Out That Essays on
Boxwood May Be Paid For Directly--Contest Open Until
February First.

In a recent letter to Dean
Brush the.Lewis & Valentine Company, landscape gardeners arid
nursery experts, make the announcement that their essay contest, announced in THE NEWS-LET
TER of November 20, will have its
date of closing extended from
January 1 to February 1.
As before announced, the essays
will be on the- subject of old Suffruticose boxwood, the prizes
ranging from $25 to $100. The essays will be published in a garden
magazine, forming a series of articles on the boxwood.
Dean Brush expresses himself
as disappointed at the lack of interest shown in the contest, as he
considers it an excellent opportunity for any Hopkins man. It
is- possible that any essays received will be paid for directly, instead of on a competitive basis,
if an insufficient number to form
a contest are received.

ATTENTION!

MUSICAL CLUBS BEGIN SEASON
THIS WEEK AT PHIPP'S CLINIC

Although no program for the
entire season has been laid out
for the combined musical clubs, a
few of the more important engagements have already been ,determined.
On December 19, a concert will
be held at the Phipps Clinic, and
a concert and dance will be held
at St. Michaels and All Angels
on January 19, 1917. In the latter part of February the clubs will
visit Tome Institute.
The future of music at Johns
Hopkins, according to a prominent member of the Mandolin
club, looks particularly bright.
The work this year has been interesting and instructive, especially
that under the direction of Mr.
McCauley, who has proved a distinct success as coach of the Mandolin club. There is, howeveir, an
excellent opening for more good
material. Practice will be held
regularly on Saturdays at 1.30
P. M., and on Tuesday and Thursday afternoons. Notices are posted
on the bulletin board in the postoffice.

INTERCLASS MEET IN JANUARY
Schaun Elected Captain of the Sophomore
Track Team--Freshmen Suspected
of Having Dark Horses Concealed in Their Ranks.

At a meeting held on last Thursday of the Class of 1919, Georg
Schaun was elected captain of the
sophomore track team. Last year
Schaun ran on the victorious
freshman relay team in the exciting dual meet between the
freshman and sophomore classes,
and hopes this year to lead his
team to a victory over the sprinters of the Class of 1920.
A definite date has not yet been
arranged for the meet, but it is
expected that the contest will be
held this year on January 20.
Although practically all the stars
of last year's team will represent
the sophomore class again, there
is also much good material among
the freshmen. Beverly Smith, last
year's crack sprinter of City Colcollege, is considered one of their
best men.
The point winners of last year,
who are the mainstays of the
sophomore team, are Weech, winner of the broad jump and prominent in the short (lashes; A. Guttmacher, who won second in the
half-mile; Haskell, Williams,
Schaun, Sonneborn and Reed, the
last two winning first and second,
respectively, in the shot-put. The
1919 Track team is also materially
strengthened by the addition of
Mellamet, who entered the class
this fall. Among the other promising men are Cronin, Strom, M.
Guttmacher, Miegel and Johnson.
SCIENTIFIC ASSOCIATION PLANS
LECTURE SERIES BY FACULTY

The Scientific Association is
planning a series of lectures to be
given on certain Wednesday afternoons by members of the faculty,
These lectures will be open to the
public, but are primarily intended
for the faculty and students. The
topics will be of general interest
and will illustrate to the University public types of problems with
which the famous scientfic men of
our staff are dealing.
The opening lecture will be
given in the Donovan Room at
4.30 o'clock Wednesday afternoon,
December 20, by Dr. William Bullock Clark on the work of the
Maryland Geological Survey. Doctor Clark is State Geologist, as
well as the head of the Geological
Department of the University,
and will explain the highly interesting and important geological
work he is doing for the State.

HOPKINS LOSES TO NAVY FIVE BATTALION NOW HAS UNIFORMS
' Independents Defeated, 59 to 16—Midshipmen Have Strong Team—Black
and Blue Quintet Still Lacking in Team Work.

Hopkins Corps at Last Attired in Regulation Soldier Garb—Lieut. Elliott
Given Two Assistants by
War Department.

Playing with an utter lack of
teamwork and opposed'by a team
whose height proved too great an
advantage, the Johns Hopkins
Independent Basket-ball team
came out of the Navy grind on
the short end of a 59 to 16 score:
The score does not indicate the
closeness of the game, for the
Black and Blue team fought every
inch of the way, but the defense
was unaided by the forwards
when Navy sent her squadron under the goal, and it was a case of
the big man getting the ball.
Navy had a heavy team and
along with this, the ability to play
over the heads of the local contingent gave them an easy victory.
The whole Navy team played well,
but the brunt of the work was
done by Von Heimberg, the
gigantic center, who swept the ball
around at will from the pivot position, and who was entirely out
of reach when playing under the
basket.
The first half ended with the
score of 29 to 6, and the second
was going in about the same proportion when both teams put in
their substitutes.
The selection of the Hopkins
Players was thought to be the
best, and probably was at the
time, but the line-up for the next
game, after the holidays, must
have a pair of faster forwards and
a jumping center if Hopkins is to
cope with the scheduled teams.
There were no stars for Hopkins every man fought individually, but not as a unit of the
necessary machine for winning
games, and the lack of condition
told heavily.
An added game to the basketball schedule which -should prove
interesting was arranged on Saturday by the local management.
Loyola College will be played in
the Richmond Market Armory on
January 13, 1917. This, along
with the game with the University
of Maryland on January 5, will
give the local followers a chance
to see the Hopkins five in action.

The Action of the Omicron Delta Kappa.

Throughout this year,'the conviction has been growing among
the students of the University,
.that, in regard to the athletic
situation, in the words .of the
soothsayer, "Something, somewhere, was amiss." That conviction, of course, is not the product
of a single year; for more than a
decade, it huts been widely recognized that athletics at Hopkins
had to con tend with obstacles
which. in themselves, offered more
formidable barriers to success
than did any opposing team. With
this year,. however, the question
arose once more: Are those difficulties inherent? Is there not
some way in which Hopkins teams
can compete under conditions at
least approximately equal to those
Qf their rivals'?
The cry for undergraduate footha 11 which has been echoing about
the University this fall was' not
due to the fact that a large number of people believed that graduates had no right to play upon
Hopkins elevens; it was due only
to. the fact that the present system, under which graduates
played, was believed unsuccessful.
That the dissatisfaction with
present conditions has been rather

general may be seen by a cursory
glance through this season's Mail
Bag—and such 'a glance will
show, with equal clearness, that
the number of remedies offered
has been'almost equal to the number of writers.
That, frankly, is the present
status; general dissatisfaction
with existing conditions, somewhat vague understanding among
the majority of undergraduates of
the causes which bring those conditions about, and, withal, a
investigation and
patent need
sane, logical, considered action—
action which shall represent a
definite and permanent policy.
In voting last Thursday night
that President Goodnow be requestea to appoint a committee,
with representatives from the undergraduates, the Medical School,
the faculty, and the alumni, to
make such investigation and to
take such action, the OmicrOn
Delta Kappa took a step which,
THE NEWS-LETTER believes, will
meet with the hearty commendation and support of the entire
University. That President Good110W will grant the petition of the
society, to those 'Who know of the
keen and' active interest which he
takes in every Hopkins problem,
is beyond all question,. ,it is
equally undoubted that' the comni III0V will be composed of men
W Ito know, the athletic situation
at. Hopkins with the intimacy,
that -.comes of personal association, and who .at the same time
will be truly representative of
every Hopkins interest.
The work of the committee will
not be con fined to the question'of
undergraduate football alone. In
fact, as TnE NEWS-LETTER sees it,
the football' situation, can be
solved, not by laying the emphasis
of the discussion upon the merit
of eligibility rules, but by laying
it upon the consideration of just
how daylight practice for, the
eleyelf can be assured--whatever
be the constituency or the eleven
oloing the practicing. The committee, however, will go far beyond that point-Lit will ,study ;the
athletic situation at Hopkins in
general, will consider all possible
policies that can b pursued, will
decide upon one, .and, with 'all
lime force of its personnel, will
work to See that ,policy made the
policy of the University.,
Such a course is not only the
best possible course—it is the only
possible course.' Had it not' been
for such a committee (for its ap-

pointiuent can be taken as a matter of granted), any steps that
might have been taken would
have been sporadic, temporary,
and sectional.
There is another aspect connected with the idea of this investigation connnittee, however,
other than that of its momentous
bearing upon the future of athletics at Hopkins. In standing as
sponsor for the idea, the Omicron
Delta Kappa justifies its existence as a Hopkins institution—
proves, once for all, that it is not
merely an honorary society, designed as the end of a process
rather than the beginning. That
society is destined to play a large
part in the development of the
University for one single reason:
It is a focus. It brings representatives of Hopkins activities
into a common bond, and, in so
doing, it enables them, as a body,
to take the initiative in action,
which, without that initiative,
might never materialize. Some
such step as this was necessary
to bring the purpose of the Omicron Delta Kappa home to the
II ndergraduate body; the chief
value of the step, both from the
standpoint of the athletic situation which it is intended to

nursery experts, make the announcement that their essay contest, announced in THE NEWS-LET

magazine, forming a series of articles on the boxwood.

considers it an excellent opportunity for any Hopkins man. It
is- possible that any essays received will be paid for directly, instead of on a competitive basis,

INTERCLASS MEET IN JANUARY
Schaun Elected Captain of the Sophomore
Track Team--Freshmen Suspected
of Having Dark Horses Concealed in Their Ranks.

At a meeting held on last Thursday of the Class of 1919, Georg
Schaun was elected captain of the
sophomore track team. Last year
Schaun ran on the victorious
freshman relay team in the exciting dual meet between the
freshman and sophomore classes,
and hopes this year to lead his
team to a victory over the sprinters of the Class of 1920.
A definite date has not yet been
arranged for the meet, but it is
expected that the contest will be
held this year on January 20.
Although practically all the stars
of last year's team will represent
the sophomore class again, there
is also much good material among
the freshmen. Beverly Smith, last
year's crack sprinter of City Colcollege, is considered one of their
best men.
The point winners of last year,
who are the mainstays of the
sophomore team, are Weech, winner of the broad jump and prominent in the short (lashes; A. Guttmacher, who won second in the
half-mile; Haskell, Williams,
Schaun, Sonneborn and Reed, the
last two winning first and second,
respectively, in the shot-put. The
1919 Track team is also materially
strengthened by the addition of
Mellamet, who entered the class
this fall. Among the other promising men are Cronin, Strom, M.
Guttmacher, Miegel and Johnson.

The lacrosse organization meeting was held last Thursday at 5

man signified his intention of
coming out for the team, whether

Doctor Abercrombie as the first
speaker. After complimenting the
management for holding the meeting at Homewood, the doctor
Spoke of the gymnasium and cage
Which he hoped would soon be
erected at Homewood, of the plans
for interclass lacrosse games, and
of the necessity for individual
practice in vacant periods and at
the lunch hour.

although the ., games cannot be
definitely announced until they
have been approved by the Athletic Board. Besides the other
teams of the South Lacrosse
League, however, the following
teams will in all probability be

everyone.

man who came out and practiced
hard had as good a show as anyone else for making the team.

bench, because it worried the opposing team.

his famous "historic" talk. He

learn the individual style of each

to adhere to the original plan.

week, through a telegram. The

further prolonged, wired Virstatement

the possibility of a tie. The Hopkins Council hopes that the final
subject will be selected by Friday,
so that tryouts for the Interclass
Debate, which is to take part on
March 3, can be held before the
Christmas holidays.
